awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG: Edge Computing for Bringing Smart Services to Under-served Urban Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
Today we are entirely dependent on centralized infrastructures (aka Cloud) for pretty much all our everyday activities such as online education, neighborhood apps, access to driving directions, and restaurant suggestions in a neighborhood. This reliance on the Cloud has serious implications. Most importantly it is one of the primary causes for the increasing digital divide between the affluent and under¬served communities. The thesis of this proposal is that such reliance on a centralized infrastructure is the bane of under¬served communities blocking them from reaping the benefits of information services that are available at the fingertips of residents in affluent communities. Ubiquitous availability of low-cost software services that are tailored to the needs of the community and pertinent to the local conditions without reliance on the Cloud are key factors in enhancing the capabilities of such communities. The key hypothesis to be validated through the planning grant is the power of edge computing to address the digital divide and future¬proof these under¬served urban communities. The findings from the planning grant will help reveal feasible technological interventions for future¬proofing under¬served urban communities from the digital divide. There is promise that the results of this research could be replicated elsewhere leading to a positive impact on the lives of under-served communities nation¬wide, if the hypotheses of the larger research vision is validated by the data collection being done through this planning grant.

Using the Westside communities of Atlanta as an exemplar for under¬served urban neighborhoods, the planning grant wishes to carry out the following pilots along the technology dimension: (a) edge¬compute based video¬conferencing solutions for the residents of the community (e.g., for meetings of the stakeholders, tutoring help for students, etc.) ; (b) edge¬compute based smart prefetching of content pertinent to the needs of the residents (e.g., entertainment, videos and presentations pertaining to school work, etc.) ; and (c) ad hoc connectivity solutions to bring WiFi hotspots to different neighborhoods. Along the societal dimension, the project will recruit participants (about 30) representing different demographic groups (such as community leaders, teachers, students, mentors, and local residents) for using the technology pilots. The data collection from the user group will consist of: (a) general understanding of the pressing needs of the community; (b) specific requirements of the focus groups for identifying the types of content to be prefetched and/or cached in the edge nodes; and (c) user experience on the technology pilots.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Today we are entirely dependent on centralized infrastructures (aka Cloud) for pretty much all our everyday activities such as online education, neighborhood apps, access to driving directions, and restaurant suggestions in a neighborhood. This reliance on the Cloud has serious implications. Most importantly it is one of the primary causes for the increasing digital divide between the affluent and underserved communities. The thesis of this proposal is that such reliance on a centralized infrastructure is the bane of underserved communities blocking them from reaping the benefits of information services that are available at the fingertips of residents in affluent communities. Ubiquitous availability of low-cost software services that are tailored to the needs of the community and pertinent to the local conditions without reliance on the Cloud are key factors in enhancing the capabilities of such communities. The key hypothesis we set out to validate through the planning grant is the power of edge computing to address the digital divide and futureproof these underserved urban communities.

 

The planning grant resulted in the technological nuggets:

1) We demonstrated the capability of the long-distance WiFi link in extending Internetcoverage to a different building on our campus. We have permanently establishedparabolic antennas between two buildings on campus and have demonstrated WiFiextension capabilities over the long-distance WiFi link. The link distance is severalhundred meters and the obtained throughput is close to 100 Mbps.

2) We demonstrated the above capabilities to stakeholders from the WashingtonMemorial High School and Raising Expectations NGO.

3) We have created a working prototype of a video conferencing server hosted on alow-cost Intel NUC. The server can host video calls wirelessly over a local areanetwork created by connecting mesh routers.

 

On the societal front:

1) The PIs (Professors Ramachandran and Dhekne) and senior PhD students (Ms. Manasvini Sethuraman and Mr. Anirudh Sarma) visited the Washington memorial high school and met with their university outreach person (Ms. Victoria Bambo). We discussed the strategies for raising the aspirational levels of the high school students. These included tutoring sessions for the students conducted by our graduate students, and periodic visits by selected high school students to the labs of the PIs to broaden their horizon.

2) Unfortunately, the above plans did not fructify since the school was going through their own challenges with personnel retention in the aftermath of the pandemic (huge attrition of teachers and technical personnel choosing not to return to work after the pandemic). Even our contact person Ms. Victoria Bambo is no longer with the school.

3) We made connections with a councilman from the Westside C. T. Martin, and he is excited about our plans for raising the aspiration levels of middle school and high school children from the Westside. He has promised to work with us as move forward to graduate to a full proposal.

 

PI meeting:

Presented a poster at the NSF SCC PI Meeting in Vanderbilt University, February2024 (JPG attached)

 

 

The results from the planning grant were disseminated through two scholarly publications in premier conference venues.  One student, Ms. Manasvini Sethuraman who worked on the planning grant graduated in 2024.  For the duration of the planning grant, Ms. Manasvini Sethuraman and Mr. Anirudh Sarma were the core students who worked on aspects of the planning grant. They benefited from the vibrant atmosphere prevalent in the PI’s Embedded Pervasive Lab (EPL) and interactions with the other PhD level students (Enrique Saurez, Harshit Gupta, Andy Xu, Adam Hall, Difei Cao, Jinsun Yoo, Tyler Landle, and Alan Nussbaum) who were working on research adjacencies to the focus of the planning grant.   Through the life of this planning grant, 2 PhD students, 3 MS students, and 6 undergraduate students participated in the research associated with this project.
